coredata.dc:title: Investigation of the use of extended surfaces in paraffin wax phase change material in thermal management of a cylindrical lithium-ion battery: Applicable in the aerospace industry
coredata.prism:copyright: Â© 2021 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Chen, Haiji
Abidi, Awatef
Hussein, Ahmed Kadhim
Younis, Obai
Degani, Mohamed
Heidarshenas, Behzad
coredata.dc:description: The use of phase change materials (PCMs) for cooling lithium-ion batteries is examined in this research. Because of the unique benefits of lithium-ion batteries, their use in electric cars has gotten a lot of attention. The lithium-ion battery is one of the most extensively utilized components as the heart of a hybrid car. These batteries generate a lot of heat while charging or discharging. If the batteries are not correctly handled, their life will be drastically shortened. In this study, a cylindrical battery is submerged in a PCM-filled chamber. Several fins of the same length are placed on the battery. The aim is to find the ideal battery compartment size and fin count to lower maximum battery temperature during the discharging process. COMSOL Multiphysics commercial software is used for the simulations. The results show that the battery with 15 fins has the best PCM melting performance at the beginning of cooling process. After one third of the cooling time, the maximum melting of PCM that is equal to 26.159% takes place. Also, in the entire cooling process, the lowest maximum temperature and the maximum volume fraction of the liquid occur when the number of fins is 9. The battery temperature rises as the number of fins increases beyond nine. Furthermore, an enclosure with the lowest maximum temperature is supplied to enclosure the lithium-ion battery.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Li-ion battery
PCM
Fin
Cooling
Thermal management

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The use of phase change materials (PCMs) for cooling lithium-ion batteries is examined in this research. Because of the unique benefits of lithium-ion batteries, their use in electric cars has gotten a lot of attention. The lithium-ion battery is one of the most extensively utilized components as the heart of a hybrid car. These batteries generate a lot of heat while charging or discharging. If the batteries are not correctly handled, their life will be drastically shortened. In this study, a cylindrical battery is submerged in a PCM-filled chamber. Several fins of the same length are placed on the battery. The aim is to find the ideal battery compartment size and fin count to lower maximum battery temperature during the discharging process. COMSOL Multiphysics commercial software is used for the simulations. The results show that the battery with 15 fins has the best PCM melting performance at the beginning of cooling process. After one third of the cooling time, the maximum melting of PCM that is equal to 26.159% takes place. Also, in the entire cooling process, the lowest maximum temperature and the maximum volume fraction of the liquid occur when the number of fins is 9. The battery temperature rises as the number of fins increases beyond nine. Furthermore, an enclosure with the lowest maximum temperature is supplied to enclosure the lithium-ion battery.

ce:def-description.ce:para: Heat due to a short circuit inside the battery
Heat generated due to abuse conditions

ce:section.ce:para: The increasing disparity between global energy supply and demand has posed a significant challenge for the engineering community in meeting energy demands [1â4]. Therefore, many energy management associations have been formed for energy saving in industries and home devices [5â9]. Researchers have also aimed to reduce energy consumption in practical devices using various methods [10â15]. Optimizing the use of fluids by varying heat transfer and changing the geometry of various devices have been two of the researchers' strategies [16â20]. Meanwhile, researchers have used different numerical methods due to the reduction of research costs [21â25]. With the rapid growth of technology in the field of hybrid vehicles, the urgent need for storage, the optimal use of thermal energy, and the design of new generation batteries have become increasingly important [26â30]. The design of heat control of such devices, the choice of the appropriate material is very important. The material must have a high specific heat. High thermal conductivity is also required for rapid absorption or rejection of heat by these materials. Thermal design's main goal is to offer a sufficient method of removing heat from the battery. Active cooling systems, which utilize air or liquid movement to transfer and reject heat, may help with this. Passive cooling system transfers or rejects heat by conduction, radiation, or free convection of air or liquid [31,32]. Using active cooling system or the utilizing a cooling fluid to absorb the heat rejected will consume more energy and complicate the system. The use of phase change capability, which does not require the use of power for cooling, has been the focus of many scientists as a passive cooling method [33â37]. Various techniques for thermal management of lithium-ion batteries have been investigated to far, with passive solutions receiving the most attention owing to their lower cost. As mentioned, the use of PCMs next to the battery can create a uniform temperature on the battery [38â42]. Many investigations have been done on the use of PCMs in cooling systems [43â45]. For instance, the work of the Radhakrishnan and Balakrishnan [46]. They looked at the impact of having a PCM in the area surrounding the heat transfer fluid. For studying the phase transition of materials in capsules in a cavity, Zivkovic and Fujii [47] devised a simple computer model. A mathematical model based on the enthalpy formulation was developed in this study. Ianniciello etÂ al. [48] evaluated PCMs in battery thermal management systems and demonstrated that different studies have been performed in the area of PCMs and the optimality of utilizing these materials rather to traditional techniques such as air-cooled and forced water-cooled ones. Using these materials, the maximum working temperatures are reduced and the temperature differences become more uniform. Water-cooled systems, due to their inability to be used in small scales due to the piping network, require alternatives such as the use of PCMs or thermoelectric devices for use in the scale of battery modules. Arora [49] introduced an alternative method instead of conventional cooling ones by classifying the possible methods for managing the battery temperature of electric vehicles, as well as their advantages and disadvantages.

Al-Hallaj and Selman [50] developed and experimented a prototype cooling system with PCMs. They concluded that the cooling system with PCM is a suitable alternative to conventional cooling systems. In another study, it was found that using PCM causes the temperature to be uniform in the battery during discharging process [51]. Patel and Rathod [52] assessed a battery temperature management system, passive cooling, PCM, and heat pipe. Their results showed that the use of PCMs along with heat pipes is recommended due to its ease of use and higher efficiency than other cooling methods. However, for battery functioning, a system must be able to offer the necessary temperature range. Kurklu etÂ al. [53] created a mathematical model to estimate a polypropylene pipe's thermal performance. Domanski and Fellah [54] looked at the second-law efficiency of PCM-based thermal energy storage devices. Liu etÂ al. [55] performed another research. They looked studied the impact of PCMs on the performance of lithium-ion batteries. Because of their excellent heat absorption, their findings revealed that using PCMs for the cooling system keeps the battery's operating temperature within the acceptable operating range. Simultaneous use of fillers such as graphite and foam, which have high thermal conductivity, enhances their efficiency.

Due to the high costs of using air-cooled or water-cooled methods, the use of PCMs for the cooling system can be an easy and inexpensive alternative approach. Therefore, recent developments as well as suggestions for the effective use of these materials for cooling systems are discussed. In this study, a passive method is investigated for lithium-ion battery cooling by using PCMs. The advantage of materials with the ability to change the phase is their specific heat and latent heat. In this paper, the battery enclosure and PCMs are investigated. Also, the battery performance is examined by placing the extended surfaces on the battery. The use of fins and PCM for thermal management of battery and change of PCM chamber is the main innovation of the present work.
In this paper, the cooling of LiPF6 cylindrical battery, whose geometric and thermal characteristics are given in TableÂ 1 , is evaluated.
Fig.Â 1 shows a schematic of the battery. Fig.Â 1 depicts that the battery can be cooled better by placing the fins on the battery.

The heat generated in the battery can be examined in three main ways:
â¢
Ohmic heat;
â¢
Heat generated due to bipolar formation;
â¢
Heat generated due to chemical reactions.

The maximum heat output of the battery in terms of different discharging rates is given in TableÂ 2
[56].

It is also possible to obtain the heat generated in the battery by modeling the battery equations numerically. In this study, chemical reactions performed in the battery cause heat to be generated in the battery, leading to the generation of heat flux in the battery. The governing equations of the battery heating system are written as follows [57â59]:

source terms is used to set the velocity to zero in the momentum equation. The zeroing of the velocity takes place gradually so that the finite velocity in the liquid phase is reduced when there is a phase change and the liquid becomes solid.

where

is the melting temperature. The energy equation for all three regions is completely solved. Since the purpose of battery cooling is considered for summer temperature, the material should be selected based on ambient temperature in different seasons so that it does not change phase at ambient temperature. The melting temperature of the material, on the other hand, should not be outside of the acceptable range for optimum battery performance. Paraffin wax is used for battery cooling for the reasons stated above [61â63]. TableÂ 3 presents the properties of paraffin used with a direct alkane chain (CH3(CH2)16CH3).

Many of the articles published today use numerical methods [66â70]. The advantages of numerical methods such as higher speed have attracted many researchers [71â75]. In this study, the numerical method has been used to conduct research. The goal of this research is to use PCMs to explore and simulate the cooling of lithium-ion batteries. Thus, the cooling of the battery is examined using steel fins and free convection and insulated boundary conditions. For numerical simulation, a commercial software is used. The temporal solidification and melting term is discretized using the first-order forward scheme and the spatial terms using the second-order forward approximation.

The geometrical parameters of the battery are given in Fig.Â 1. In this figure, H is the height of the battery, D is its diameter, h is the height of the fin, t is the thickness of the fin, n is the number of fins, r is the thickness of the layer of PCM on sidewall, and l is the thickness of PCM on the upper side of the battery.

In order to check the independence of the results from the grid size (number of elements), the results should be assessed for different grid sizes. The grid generated on the geometry is shown in Fig.Â 2 . Battery cooling is examined with a number of different elements and the results are compared.

Since the aim is to cool the battery for a certain period of time, the influential parameter in system design is the maximum temperature of the battery. Therefore, the maximum battery temperature for different grid elements is examined. TableÂ 4 shows the maximum battery temperature for different grids. As shown in TableÂ 4, the maximum battery temperature does not change significantly over a period of two hours by changing the spatial pitch, or in other words by quadrupling the number of elements. The grid that is selected is shown in Fig.Â 2.

To validate the findings of the current study, a comparison with Yang etÂ al. [76] is conducted first. The cooling performance of lithium-ion batteries and air-cooled cooling systems was studied by Yang etÂ al. [76]. They compared various LiFePO4 battery pack cell designs. The temperature of the battery surface (Fig.Â 3 ) obtained in this study agrees well with their findings, indicating that the current solution technique may be utilized to get the results.

For the second verifications a comparison is made with the results reported by Ramandi etÂ al. [61] to estimate the melting process in a PCM. Figs.Â 4 and 4 show the results obtained from the present study and the results reported by Ramandi study [61] for the maximum temperature of the battery.

As can be observed, the findings of the technique used in this study and those of their research are quite similar, indicating that the geometric parameters approach utilized in this study is legitimate.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Comparison of cooling process using PCMs and air-cooled method and selection of suitable chamber for using PCMs
ce:section.ce:para: In this section, the cooling of the battery using PCMs is discussed. The volume of PCMs around the battery is changed to reach an appropriate volume for cooling the battery at two hours. The geometric parameters used in this section, which are described in Fig.Â 1, are given in TableÂ 5 .

According to the contours shown in Figs. 5 and 6 , it can be seen that as the battery temperature increases, more PCM becomes liquid over time. In fact, in passive cooling, the temperature enhancement has three different stages. Before 2000Â s, the battery temperature is almost constant. In this case, the PCM between the fins is in the process of melting. After complete melting of the PCM, the temperature increment slope enhances, however, the temperature increase process is slower compared to air-cooled method due to melting of the remaining amount of PCM.
The isothermal lines also show that the maximum temperature occurs in the center of the battery and the fins transfer the generated heat to the PCM.

The temperature and melting contours of PCMs are given by changing the chamber height. According to Fig.Â 7 , the use of chamber with higher height and width will consume more materials, increasing the cost in battery cooling process. Therefore, the use of an optimal size of chamber is needed for calculations. Since the battery cooling occurs for two hours, a volume of PCM is selected with 13-mm thickness on the side and 10-mm thickness on the upper side. In fact, the size of the chamber is 60 by 80.

Fig.Â 8 compares active and passive cooling methods. According to the results obtained and as shown in Fig.Â 8, the temperature of the battery initially increases with a steep slope in air-cooled system. However, the heat transfer in the battery reaches an equilibrium state after one hour and its temperature remains almost constant. Finally, when all the PCM around the battery is melted, the process of increasing the temperature of the battery is intensified. If the amount of PCM around the battery is few, the battery temperature becomes higher after two hours compared to air-cooled system.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Assessment of the free convection around the battery
ce:section.ce:para: In order to simplify the free convection condition around the battery, its value is assumed to be constant. Since the size of the battery is small, the assumption is valid compared to the reality. In Fig.Â 9 , the maximum battery temperature is given over two hours for different free and forced convection coefficients.

As can be seen in Fig.Â 9, no change in the maximum temperature is observed by changing the convection coefficient in the free convection range. This result confirms the assumption assumed for the convection condition. Because changing the free convection coefficient from 10 to 15 has no effect on the maximum temperature. Also, by changing the convection coefficient and considering the forced convection, a two-degree decrease occurs in the maximum temperature of the battery, which shows that the use of fin and the creation of disturbance in the surrounding air is efficient and improves cooling process. Liquid mass fraction is a parameter that indicates the ratio of the mass of phase changed material to the mass of the whole PCM in the chamber. According to this definition, at the beginning of the heat transfer process, Fig.Â 9 shows the mass fraction of the liquid around the battery for two hours for different free and forced convection coefficients. As can be seen in Fig.Â 9, the fluid fraction decreases by changing the type of boundary condition from the thermal insulation to the convection (free and forced). This phenomenon is due to that it is not possible to remove the generated heat from the battery when the insulated boundary condition is used, i.e. the total heat generated in the battery is spent on changing the phase of PCM from solid to liquid. As a result, the mass fraction of liquid increases. On the other hand, as the boundary condition changes from free to forced convection, similar phenomena occur due to the phase change of the PCM.

The impact of the number of fins is shown in Fig.Â 10 by temperature and melting counters. As can be observed, increasing the number of fins improves heat transfer and increases the volume% of melting. It's also worth noting that when the number of fins on isothermal lines grows, the lines get denser, indicating an increase in heat transfer. The maximum temperature is lowered as the number of fins is increased; however, this reduction is limited to up to 9 fins, beyond which the maximum temperature does not drop and instead increases. As a result, when the number of fins is 9, the greatest performance is achieved.

Liquid mass fraction contour for the battery with 9 fins is shown at different times. Before 200Â s, due to low thermal conductivity of PCM, the battery temperature increases with a sharp slope. Fig.Â 11 confirms this explanation. When the PCM starts to melt, the battery temperature increases during two stages. The first is related to the state in which the PCM between the fins melts for the battery with 10 fins during 4000Â s. In the second stage, the rest of the PCM is melted around the battery.

According to Fig.Â 12 , the increasing of the battery temperature where the PCM in the space between the fins is not completely melted, is less than the case where complete melting occurs. The fin thickness is assumed to be 0.2Â mm and the optimal fin height is obtained. Fig.Â 11 shows the maximum temperature of the battery in terms of time, indicating that the battery with 9 fins has the best performance. In this figure, the improvement in battery cooling performance using the fin is compared to the case without fins. In addition, the maximum temperature in the battery takes place during three different phases, which can be justified by using the fluid mass fraction contours. Fig.Â 12 shows the average mass fraction of liquid over a period of two hours. As can be seen, the battery with 9 fins has a maximum liquid mass fraction for the entire cooling time interval, indicating the optimal performance of the battery with 9 fins in the presence of PCM.
The fins are utilized to enhance the thermal conductivity during cooling in this research to improve the cooling performance of the battery utilizing PCM. The following results are obtained:

In air-cooled method, the temperature of the battery rises steeply at first. After one hour, the heat transfer in the battery reaches equilibrium state and the temperature remains almost constant. But, in passive cooling, the temperature enhances with different slopes. As long as the PCM does not melt completely, cooling with PCM is preferable than cooling with air. The maximum battery temperature does not vary much when the convection coefficient is changed within the free convection range. Considering forced convection, however, results in a significant reduction in the battery's maximum temperature. This finding demonstrates that utilizing the fins and generating turbulence in the air flow around the battery has a substantial impact on battery cooling and performance. When compared to cases without fins, passive cooling of the battery employing fins has greater performance for various fin configurations. When the fin is used to cool a battery, increasing the number of fins enhances cooling performance. However, this benefit only lasts until the number of fins reaches 9. The maximum battery temperature rises when the number of fins exceeds nine. Of other words, as the number of fins goes below nine, so does the maximum temperature in the battery. When the number of fins exceeds 9, the maximum fin temperature either remains constant or increases.

Haiji Chen: Writing â original draft, Validation. Awatef Abidi: Writing â original draft. Ahmed Kadhim Hussein: Writing â review & editing, Conceptualization. Obai Younis: Writing â review & editing. Mohamed Degani: Conceptualization. Behzad Heidarshenas: Supervision, Writing â review & editing.
